This is a challenging time for Alaskans, but we‚Äôll get through this together. @lisamurkowski, @SenDanSullivan, and I penned an op-ed to update Alaskans on what we‚Äôre doing in Congress to turn the tide in the COVID-19 pandemic. Read it here: https://t.co/DTALickEzA via @adndotcom

The CARES Act also provides needed support for our Native communities by providing funding to help health care providers, schools, and communities mitigate the impacts of COVID-19. Click here to learn more: https://t.co/pBqSdvOHgv

Individuals and families will receive direct cash payments; grants and loans will be available to help small businesses meet payroll and rent; unemployment insurance will be temporarily expanded, and distressed industries that employ thousands of Americans will receive support.

Too many families have found themselves suffering from unemployment or underemployment through no fault of their own. Today's bill takes necessary steps to support Americans through this challenging time.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact families across our country, not only in terms of their physical wellbeing, but also their financial health. Countless families in Alaska have been forced to stay home or laid off, but the bills continue piling up.
BREAKING: I helped the House pass the CARES Act ‚Äì emergency COVID-19 legislation that has now been signed into law by @POTUS.  https://t.co/EfOeBoXnHI

#COVID19's impact is very real, growing, and causing all of us to adjust our habits as the situation changes. Weeks ago, I didn't fully grasp the severity of this crisis, but clearly, we are in the midst of a public health emergency. Stay safe Alaska! https://t.co/hsyTri24bU

Read our letter to @VP urging the establishment of two task forces to combat COVID-19. One to expedite the development of vaccines, and a second to address medical supply shortages in Alaska and across the country: https://t.co/Bvy0a4CHqM

Time is of the essence. Medical supply shortages and bureaucratic red tape threaten not only Americans‚Äô access to necessary medical equipment, but may also be making the development of COVID-19 vaccines more difficult.

Countless families rely on afterschool programs to take care of Alaska‚Äôs young people, particularly through the nutritious snacks and meals they provide.

Thank you, Alaska. May God Bless our great nation!

Accomplishing big things with you on behalf of Alaska is very fulfilling, and the love and support I receive every time I'm home makes me a truly fortunate man. In the years ahead, let's keep working together to make our state and country a better place for future generations.

Having served under nine presidents and in both the minority and the majority, I know that there is nothing this country can't do and no challenge we can't overcome by being willing to listen and work with one another.
I love and respect this institution, and it is a privilege to have worked with over two-thousand other Members throughout my tenure.
It is my humble honor to come to work to serve the people of our great state, and I'm just as energized today as I was back then.
On this day in 1973, Alaskans put their trust in me and allowed me the opportunity to serve them in the House of Representatives. https://t.co/imwMX4NVyH

On Martin Luther King Jr. Day, we celebrate the life and work of Dr. King. His fight for civil rights changed history, and our nation will forever owe him a debt of gratitude. May we honor his legacy by always standing up for what is right. #MLKDay #MLK https://t.co/1PDVeAueqP
Read more about this American hero: https://t.co/jd90E1kXmA #CVN81

He may not have known it at the time, but his incredible story helped further the cause of civil rights, and secured him a well-deserved place in American history. May God bless the future sailors of the USS Doris Miller (CVN 81)!

His actions that day not only helped save lives, they also earned him commendation from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox and the Navy Cross, which was presented to him personally by Admiral Chester Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet. https://t.co/k180zbHdri

Miller served in a segregated Navy and was prohibited from using guns simply because of his race. This didn‚Äôt stop him from springing into action and valiantly manning a Browning anti-aircraft machine gun until he ran out of ammunition during Japan‚Äôs attack on Pearl Harbor.

Tomorrow, the @USNavy will officially name a future Gerald R. Ford-class aircraft carrier after Pearl Harbor hero Mess Attendant 2nd Class Doris ‚ÄúDorie‚Äù Miller, the first African American to receive the Navy Cross for valor. https://t.co/saf1mxb4pQ

Still, it‚Äôs exactly what is happening to the persecuted Christians in the Middle East, the Rohingya Muslims facing genocide in China, and our Jewish friends and neighbors who have been threatened and harmed by anti-Semitism.
It‚Äôs hard to believe that in the year 2020, oppressive governments are still violating the fundamental religious rights of their citizens.
